title: 111_hr4250
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled the "Medicaid DSH Integrity Act" and highlights the importance of Medicaid DSH payments for safety net hospitals serving the poor and uninsured. Reporting and auditing requirements added in 2003 ensure proper use of DSH funds. The Medicaid DSH Integrity Act emphasizes the significance of DSH payments for safety net hospitals serving the poor and uninsured. Reporting and auditing requirements added in 2003 ensure proper use of DSH funds to assist hospitals serving low-income individuals. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services issued regulations to ensure DSH funds are used for their intended purpose of assisting hospitals serving low-income individuals. These regulations have narrowed the scope of DSH payments for many States without altering the definition of DSH-eligible. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services implemented changes to DSH policy, narrowing the scope of DSH payments for many States without altering the definition of DSH-eligible costs. Congress did not intend to reduce DSH payments under the existing program. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services implemented policy changes to narrow the scope of DSH payments, resulting in significant reductions for safety net providers participating in the Medicaid DSH program. SEC. 2. REVISION OF MEDICAID DSH AUDITING AND REPORTING REGULATIONS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with States and disproportionate share hospitals, will not enforce changes in policy related to the calculation of limits under the Medicaid DSH program. An interim final rule will be published to revise the Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will not enforce changes in policy regarding the calculation of limits under the Medicaid DSH program. An interim final rule will be published to revise Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. The interim final rule will include regulatory changes related to Medicaid DSH program limits, auditing, and reporting. The new interim final rule will implement Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, as well as include regulatory changes related to defining costs for services provided to individuals with no health insurance. The new interim final rule will implement Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, including defining costs for services provided to individuals without health insurance. CMS allows inclusion of all costs for services to uninsured patients, even if they have insurance for other services. The interim final rule implements Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, allowing states to define allowable costs in their State Medicaid plan as long as they do not exceed Medicare principles of cost reimbursement. The CMS will interpret the audit requirement language in the Social Security Act to align with the term "hospital services" and not impose a more restrictive interpretation. CMS will revise the General DSH Audit and Reporting Protocol to allow the use of either an overall cost-to-charge ratio or departmental cost-to-charge ratios. CMS will revise the General DSH Audit and Reporting Protocol to allow alternative methodologies for determining actual costs, including trending forward costs from prior years. CMS will revise regulations to permit alternative methodologies for determining actual costs, including trending forward costs from prior years. Additionally, the Social Security Act will be amended to change the initiation requirements effective as if included in the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act. The Social Security Act is amended to change the year from 2004 to 2008. The term "CMS" refers to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and "Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations" refers to a final regulation issued in December 2008. The Act defines key terms such as CMS (Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services), Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, Medicaid DSH program, and Secretary (Secretary of Health and Human Services).
